comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content: According to Wikipedia, "Wladimir Rudolf Karl Freiherr Giesl von Gieslingen (18 February 1860 – 20 April 1936), was an Austro-Hungarian general and diplomat during World War I, most famous for delivering the ultimatum to the Serbian government during the July Crisis of 1914."

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: A blog posting about the photographer: cabinetcardgallery.wordpress.com/category/photographer-pi...

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: Thanks for the information about the general, the photographer, and the date.  We'll add some information when we update the description.

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: Not so fast. This is Arthur Giesl Freiherr von Gieslingen (1857-1935) Arthur Giesl Freiherr von Gieslingen (June 19 1857 in Krakow - December 3 1935 in Vienna ) was an Austrian general and director of the Office of evidence , the military intelligence service of the imperial monarchy. He was involved both in the Mayerling affair, as well as in the Redl affair that rocked the Danube Monarchy. Source: de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Giesl_von_Gieslingen

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: www.austro-hungarian-army.co.uk/biog/giesla.htm agrees with Richard Arthur Norton and indicates that Wladimir is a younger brother. Wladimir is shown at www.austro-hungarian-army.co.uk/biog/gieslw.htm

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: Thanks for the correction (though it took me awhile to catch up with it).  We'll update our description accordingly.
